title: 103_s1367
content: Section 1 of the law applies to mailings by Senators, Senators-elect, and Senate offices from fiscal year 1994 onwards, regarding the use of the franking privilege. A mass mailing is defined as 500 or more pieces of mail with similar content, excluding direct response mailings. The franking privilege allows for mailings by Senators and Senate offices, including responses within 180 days, communications to government officials, news releases, town meeting notices, and Federal publications. The franking privilege allows Senators and Senate offices to send mailings, but mass mailings are prohibited. The chairman of the Committee on Rules and Administration of the Senate must report official mail costs quarterly in the Congressional Record. In fiscal year 1995 budget presentations, the Secretary of the Senate and the Sergeant at Arms must report expenditures for official mail activities in 1994 and 1993 for each Senate office account. No member, officer, or employee of the Senate can use appropriated funds for procuring mailing lists, except for specific types. The text chunk discusses the specific types of mailing lists that can be used with official funds, including lists from the United States Postal Service, media members, government officials, and individuals interested in a legislative topic different from previously used lists. The text discusses the criteria for considering a legislative topic different from another, based on the content of mailings used by the office during the fiscal year.
